titleStmt.title: List of ephebes participating in the second Pythaïs

body.div:
+1+ This list of 76 ephebes plus their masters and magistrates was inscribed on the southern façade of the Athenian Treasury shortly after the second Pythaïs in 128/7 BCE, together with other lists of magistrates, participants and victors (for more detail see F.Delphes III 2.3, note 1). The list was inscribed to the right of the ephebes' list for the first Pythaïs in 138/7 BCE (F.Delphes III 2.23). The text up to line 17, serving as a preceding paragraph, was inscribed on an upper block; the name lists of ephebes, written in three columns, occupyed blocks in two storeys, with the higher storey of each column bearing 16 lines, and lower storey having 15 lines.
The first line was inscribed in even distributed alignment, namely, the first letter was flush left and the last to the right, with the horizontal space evenly distributed between letters.!
+2+ Eumēlos son of Noumēnios held this priesthood in Athens for life. He is very probably the father of a Pythaïst-boy named Noumēnios son of Eumēlos, in F.Delphes III 2.11 (138/7 BCE).!
+3+ This magistrate, literally 'director ordained by Pythian Apollo' was chosen among Athenians since the fifth century BCE, according to both Plato's testimony (Pl. Leg. 9.865b-d) and epigraphic evidence (IG I3, 131, line 9). For the exegetes in the Archaic and Classical Athens, see now Valdés Guía in Mediterraneo Antico 5 (2002), especially 190 onwards. Although Suda, s.v. describes, 'there are three Pythochrestoi, whose task it is to purify those in the grip of a certain curse. Also those expounding the ancestral customs.', yet in the Hellenistic times, the sources were limited to the Pythaïs inscriptions, where only one Pythochrestos exegetes was mentioned (see in detail, Oliver, Athenian Expounders, 36–46). In the Roman period, Pythochrestos exegetes still played an important role in the Dodekaïs inscriptions, as the then exegetes Polykritos of Azenia was mentioned in all the Dodekaïs inscriptions (F.Delphes III 2.59 and 61–64), but can also be used as a title for honorific citizenship of Delphi (for instance, AIUK 8 (Broomhall), no. 5).
This Ophelas son of Habrōn of Bate belonged to a distinguished family with two other members being exegetes 'appointed by the People' (hupo dēmou kathestamemos exēgētēs): a Kallias son of Habrōn in F.Delphes III 2.5 in 106/5 BCE, and a Kallias son of Euchtēmōn in F.Delphes III 2.6 in 98/7 BCE.!
+4+ Kosmētos played an important role in funding supplies for Hellenistic ephebeias in Athens, and would receive honorific wreaths in the following year (SEG 15.104): for the ephebeia in late Hellenistic Athens, see now Perrin-Saminadayar, Éducation, culture et société à Athènes, especially 248–266.
In Hellenistic Athens, becoming instructors of ephebes was one of the exceptional ways that foreigners could play a public role, as it required qualifications (see Niku, Official Status of the Foreign Residents in Athens, 17). Their children or relatives may then get ephebic trainings or be granted Athenian citizenship. In our case, three teachers were explicitly mentioned as foreigners: the pedotribe / gymnastic master Nikōn from Berytos (today Beirut), whose relative a Nikōn from Berytos later became ephebe on Delos in 119/8 (ID 2598 I.43); hoplite master Sōtades from (most likely Cilician) Soloi; and Artemidoros from Tarsos as assistant of his master. The first two were also honoured in the following year with wreaths in Athens (SEG 15.104).!
+5+ The first letter of this line was hanged to the left.
For the Tarantine cavalry, see SEG 46.167.!
+6+ To averagely distribute the names in the two lower storeys, there was a wide vertical gap between lines 33 and 34.!
